<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 119, 645, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 280, 209]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 540, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 912, 507]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 533, 220, 548]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 571, 596]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 100, 640, 549]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{ C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{ u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{ kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{ kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{ kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{ J K}^{- 1} \text{ mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{ J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{ N m}^{2} \text{ kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{ F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{ m F}^{- 1}\right)\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{ J s}\) Stefan–Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{ W m}^{- 2} \text{ K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 585, 168, 601]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 612, 322, 630]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 612, 571, 650]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = \nu^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 662, 250, 680]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 694, 151, 711]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 725, 339, 744]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 764, 205, 781]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 795, 228, 812]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 825, 238, 842]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 662, 541, 680]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 692, 531, 711]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 718, 541, 755]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{\mathrm{s}}V}{\nu \pm \nu_{\mathrm{s}}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 764, 536, 782]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 793, 595, 812]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 816, 611, 851]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 419, 920, 453]]<|/det|>
The velocity of an object changes from an initial velocity \(u\) to a final velocity \(v\). The vectors represent these velocities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 549, 675, 570]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 707, 94, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
An object is moving with initial velocity \(u\). The object then moves with uniform acceleration \(a\) for time \(t\) until it reaches final velocity \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 752, 541, 771]]<|/det|>
Which equation describes the motion of the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 780, 134, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 780, 751, 798]]<|/det|>
\(u = v - 2at\)  B \(u = v - at\)  C \(v = u + at^2\)  D \(v = u + 2at^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 497, 89]]<|/det|> Which calculation produces a vector quantity? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 134, 118]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 101, 269, 118]]<|/det|> current \(\times\) time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 127, 482, 144]]<|/det|> final displacement – initial displacement <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 163, 134, 180]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 156, 247, 190]]<|/det|> work done time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 134, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 203, 331, 237]]<|/det|> \(\frac{1}{2} \times \text{mass} \times (\text{speed})^2\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 97, 286]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 920, 301]]<|/det|> A thermometer can be read to an accuracy of \(\pm 0.5^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). This thermometer is used to measure a temperature rise from \(40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 313, 777, 331]]<|/det|> What is the percentage uncertainty in the measurement of the temperature rise? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 134, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 342, 198, 359]]<|/det|> 0.5% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 342, 303, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 342, 364, 359]]<|/det|> 0.8% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 342, 490, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 342, 532, 359]]<|/det|> 1.3% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 342, 636, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 342, 700, 359]]<|/det|> 1.7% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 386, 97, 404]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 386, 462, 404]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the path of a golf ball. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 413, 714, 485]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 502, 920, 535]]<|/det|> Which row describes changes in the horizontal and vertical components of the golf ball's velocity when air resistance is ignored? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 546, 702, 700]]<|/det|>
horizontalvertical
Aconstant decelerationconstant acceleration downwards
Bconstant decelerationacceleration decreases upwards
then increases downwards
Cconstant velocityconstant acceleration downwards
Dconstant velocityacceleration decreases upwards
then increases downwards

The graph shows how the force \(F\) on the ball varies with time \(t\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 101, 611, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 675, 288]]<|/det|> Which graph shows how the velocity \(\nu\) of the ball varies with time \(t\)? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 295, 781, 660]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 686, 107, 704]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 686, 712, 704]]<|/det|> What is meant by the mass and by the weight of an object on the Earth? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 714, 925, 845]]<|/det|>
massweight
Aits momentum divided by its velocitythe work done in lifting it one metre
Bthe gravitational force on itthe property that resists its acceleration
Cthe pull of the Earth on itits mass divided by the acceleration of free fall
Dthe property that resists its accelerationthe pull of the Earth on it

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A thin horizontal plate of area \(0.036 \text{m}^2\) is beneath the surface of a liquid of density \(930 \text{kg} \text{m}^{- 3}\). The force on one side of the plate due to the pressure of the liquid is \(290 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 641, 135]]<|/det|>
What is the depth of the plate beneath the surface of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 144, 138, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 210, 163]]<|/det|>
0.88 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 144, 303, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 144, 368, 163]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 144, 473, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 144, 534, 163]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 144, 702, 163]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 189, 106, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 189, 838, 208]]<|/det|>
Spheres X and Y form an isolated system. The mass of Y is greater than the mass of X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 220, 366, 238]]<|/det|>
Sphere Y is initially stationary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 250, 472, 268]]<|/det|>
Sphere X collides elastically with sphere Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 510, 298]]<|/det|>
The speed of sphere X before the collision is \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 406, 328]]<|/det|>
Which statement **must** be correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 134, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 339, 920, 373]]<|/det|>
Sphere X rebounds with a speed that is greater than \(u\), and sphere Y moves off with a speed that is less than \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 380, 133, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 380, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
Sphere X rebounds with a speed that is less than \(u\), and sphere Y moves off with a speed that is also less than \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 421, 131, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 421, 707, 440]]<|/det|>
Sphere X rebounds with speed \(u\), and sphere Y remains stationary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 448, 133, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 447, 860, 466]]<|/det|>
Sphere X remains stationary, and sphere Y moves off with a speed that is less than \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 492, 106, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 491, 920, 526]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 718, 494, 736]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 473, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
A rope is attached at one end of the beam. The rope is at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the vertical and exerts a force \(F\), in newtons, on the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 520, 623, 539]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 547, 180, 565]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A box of weight \(40 \text{N}\) is pushed with a horizontal force of \(20 \text{N}\) along level ground for a distance of \(2.4 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 818, 135]]<|/det|>
The box is then lifted at constant velocity through a height of \(1.6 \text{m}\) by a vertical force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 146, 591, 165]]<|/det|>
What is the total work done on the box by the two forces?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 175, 134, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 175, 188, 193]]<|/det|>
80 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 175, 316, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[325, 175, 368, 193]]<|/det|>
110 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 175, 480, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 175, 534, 193]]<|/det|>
120 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 175, 643, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[651, 175, 700, 193]]<|/det|>
160 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 220, 107, 238]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 220, 482, 238]]<|/det|>
Which statement about efficiency is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 248, 415, 267]]<|/det|>
Efficiency does **not** have a unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 275, 134, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 275, 410, 293]]<|/det|>
The joule is a unit of efficiency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 301, 133, 319]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 301, 415, 319]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 327, 403, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
A plane wave of amplitude \(A\) is incident on a surface of area \(S\) placed so that it is perpendicular to the direction of travel of the wave. The energy per unit time reaching the surface is \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 418, 865, 437]]<|/det|>
The amplitude of the wave is increased to \(2A\) and the area of the surface is reduced to \(\frac{1}{2} S.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 452, 623, 471]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 134, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 483, 180, 502]]<|/det|>
4E

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 483, 303, 502]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 483, 346, 502]]<|/det|>
2E

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 483, 470, 502]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 483, 504, 502]]<|/det|>
E

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 483, 636, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 483, 687, 502]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{1}{2} E\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 518, 920, 553]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 564, 742, 584]]<|/det|>

The transmission axis of the filter is at angle \(\theta\) to the plane of polarisation of the incident wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 705, 636, 724]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 734, 210, 752]]<|/det|>
$A\cos \theta$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 733, 303, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 733, 386, 752]]<|/det|>
$A\cos^2\theta$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 733, 470, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 733, 552, 752]]<|/det|>
$A^2\cos\theta$

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 733, 727, 752]]<|/det|>
$A^2\cos^2\theta$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 485, 89]]<|/det|> Which wave **cannot** be a longitudinal wave? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 100, 297, 117]]<|/det|> a diffracted wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 126, 134, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 126, 295, 144]]<|/det|> a polarised wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 134, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 152, 291, 170]]<|/det|> a reflected wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 134, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 178, 299, 196]]<|/det|> a stationary wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 920, 255]]<|/det|> Microwaves are emitted from two sources at points X and Y. The two waves meet at point Z. The diagram shows the paths of the two waves. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 262, 608, 363]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 377, 556, 395]]<|/det|> The waves emitted from points X and Y are coherent. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 408, 645, 426]]<|/det|> What is a direct consequence of the two waves being coherent? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 134, 455]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 437, 655, 455]]<|/det|> There is a constant difference in the path lengths YZ and XZ. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 463, 131, 481]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 463, 715, 481]]<|/det|> There is a constant difference in phase between the two waves at Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 489, 131, 507]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 489, 769, 507]]<|/det|> There is a constant non-zero difference in frequency of the two waves at Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 131, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 515, 769, 533]]<|/det|> There is a constant non-zero difference in amplitude of the two waves at Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 559, 104, 577]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 361, 577]]<|/det|> What is the unit of resistivity? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 495, 106, 514]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 495, 855, 515]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a circuit with a cell and three resistors with resistances \(R_{1}\), \(R_{2}\) and \(R_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 463, 545]]<|/det|> The cell has negligible internal resistance. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 555, 603, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 701, 437, 720]]<|/det|> The total resistance of the circuit is \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 731, 391, 749]]<|/det|> Which equation for \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\) is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 134, 778]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 761, 299, 780]]<|/det|> \(R_{\mathrm{T}} = R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 791, 134, 810]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 789, 311, 814]]<|/det|> \(R_{\mathrm{T}} = \frac{1}{R_{1} + R_{2}} +\frac{1}{R_{3}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 828, 133, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 826, 304, 853]]<|/det|> \(\frac{1}{R_{\mathrm{T}}} = \frac{1}{R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 870, 134, 890]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 867, 311, 897]]<|/det|> \(\frac{1}{R_{\mathrm{T}}} = \frac{1}{R_{1} + R_{2}} +\frac{1}{R_{3}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 73, 883, 94]]<|/det|>
Hydrogen and deuterium can be represented by the nuclide symbols \(_1^1 \text{H}\) and \(_1^2 \text{H}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 107, 576, 127]]<|/det|>
What is a difference between hydrogen and deuterium?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 135, 134, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 135, 792, 154]]<|/det|>
The deuterium atom has twice the number of electrons as the hydrogen atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 163, 134, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 801, 181]]<|/det|>
The deuterium nucleus has a charge, but the hydrogen nucleus has no charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 189, 134, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 189, 695, 207]]<|/det|>
The deuterium nucleus has less mass than the hydrogen nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 215, 134, 233]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 215, 831, 233]]<|/det|>
The deuterium nucleus has half the charge per unit mass of the hydrogen nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 260, 107, 279]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 260, 551, 279]]<|/det|>
A radioactive sample decays by emitting \(\beta^{- }\) particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 290, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
The energy released in the decay process is the same for each nucleus that decays, but the \(\beta^{- }\) particles emitted have a continuous range of kinetic energies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 337, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains why the \(\beta^{- }\) particles are emitted with a continuous range of kinetic energies?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 380, 133, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 380, 803, 399]]<|/det|>
Some of the energy released is given to the remaining nucleons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 408, 133, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 408, 687, 426]]<|/det|>
Some of the energy released is taken by an emitted antineutrino.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 133, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 435, 656, 454]]<|/det|>
Some of the energy released is used to create the \(\beta^{- }\) particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 462, 133, 480]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 462, 663, 480]]<|/det|>
Some of the energy released is used to create a new nucleon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 504, 107, 523]]<|/det|>
